content: If you were military at one point (and from what I remember of your profile before they farked up the profile page, you were), then you have an idea of what "universal health care" means. Personally, I was born in a military hospital, was raised in the military as a dependent, and have had an ID card and military medical care for all but four (count 'em, FOUR) days of my 62+ years on this planet. I expect I'll die in some MTF, if I'm lucky, and be planted at Arlington if there's still room. So I'm sort of an expert user of "socialized medicine," and I favor it ... provided it reverts to something resembling the military system of the '60s and '70s or so. After that, the military medical system made the gross mistake of trying to pattern itself after the civilian medical model, which was busily going down the tubes with HMOs run by folks with MBAs and such, not medical folks first and foremost - great expense, much bureaucracy involving non-providers making medical decisions and so on. If they - the government - can avoid that giant landmine, it could work very well. IMNSHO.

content: We spend over double what the majority of the industrialized world spends on healthcare per capita. It is over $5,000 annually per capita. Yet we rank far lower in life expectancy and infant mortality rates. For infant mortality we rank just above Croatia and behind Cuba. For life expectancy we rank 45th behind Bosnia and Jordan. Our healthcare costs continue to skyrocket but quality goes down. The government already spends far more per person than countries with "socialized" medicine, yet the numbers show they have better healthcare than we do. The problem we have is we have a for profit medical system already paid for with public dollars. You have to pay for healthcare twice, once through payroll Medicare tax and again for private insurance. A properly done public healthcare system would improve care for most, and cost everyone less. Right now that family of four if they qualify for Medicaid makes them part of the group that costs each person in the country $1000 per year. Once you add the $1500 per person cost of Medicare we have a government cost of about $2500 for everyone of the 300,000,000 people plus the other $2500 spent on private insurance for those that don't qualify for government coverage.

content: Our current health care situation in the US is indeed crap. But, I would not recommend replacing a crappy program with an even crappier program. If the gov is put in charge of health care they will screw it up the way they did when they created our current health care system. Yep, that's right. Many forget that it was Nixon who changed our health care system to the way it is today. What Nixon did was allow the insurance companies to have complete dominion over every facet of the health care field. They can control prices, how much or how little people receive, how much a doctor gets paid, whether a person lives or dies, etc. It did not work this way before. I am sure many of you remember how it worked before this. You had health insurance the same way you had any other kind of insurance... For emergencies. If it wasn't an emergency, then you paid out of pocket. And, that my friends is what kept the cost of health care down. That is what is known as market based pricing. The doctors could not raise prices past the peoples ability to pay. I don't understand why people are not advocating going back to this way of doing things rather than thinking that the government knows its a** from a hole in the ground and can run the medical industry. The government has screwed up almost every thing it has ever gotten its hands on. Why would health care be any different? Show me one thing that the government did right and I may consider it. Until then, hell no!!!

title: UNIVERSAL HEALTH CARE

content: Afew years back, I was damned near killed by hospital malpractice. I was bleeding internally literally within minutes of dying, in a coma, when my wife arrived to help me get ready to come home the next day. SUPRISE, 4 1/2 months later , with a paralized leg, I was well enough to convaless at home. Suppose I had sued rather than negotiate a settlement? Well, we'd STILL be in discovery 4 years plus later, and as the first 2 years out of the hospital were VERY VERY difficult (I could not even pull myself up in bed) we'd be at the BEGINING. MY BEST ESTIMAte is I'd be looking at another 3 to 5 years of legal maniovering before a court date was set. The system is screwed up as the tort system has failed us. As had, obviously, the Texas system of reform. I have my ideas of how to solve rthis, and began to write it up. At this point is covers 50 pages single spaced typing, and it is not even close to being finished. I have drawn upon my 30 yearts in rthe personal insurance business, my clients and my adventures in the system. Despite my misgivings, today, our system, warts and all, is the best there is. STILL NEEDS A lot OF WORK, but NOT what Mr. Obama and Hillary want, that WOULD BE much much worse!

content: peter3_1 - I'm not making light of your situation by any means, but medical malpractice, misadventures and errors (some fatal) will happen in any medical system, whatever its structure: private, HMO, PPO, socialized. It makes no difference because healthcare providers are human, and some are better providers than others.
